thread.title: Spurs Nation: Beat writers gaze into their crystal ball
thread.title_full: Spurs Nation: Beat writers gaze into their crystal ball - San Antonio Express-News

author: Staff report
title: Spurs Nation: Beat writers gaze into their crystal ball
text:
Photo: Ben Margot /Associated Press Image 1 of / 4 4 Golden State Warriors’ Stephen Curry, left, and Klay Thompson (11) pose for photographs during an NBA basketball media day Monday, Sept. 28, 2015, in Oakland, Calif. Golden State Warriors’ Stephen Curry, left, and Klay Thompson (11) pose for photographs during an NBA basketball media day Monday, Sept. 28, 2015, in Oakland, Calif. Photo: Ben Margot /Associated Press Image 2 of 4 In this Oct. 9, 2015, file photo, Oklahoma City Thunder forward Kevin Durant (35) goes up to dunk in front of Fenerbahce Ulker forward Nikola Kalinic (33) in the third quarter of an NBA basketball preseason game in Oklahoma City. In this Oct. 9, 2015, file photo, Oklahoma City Thunder forward Kevin Durant (35) goes up to dunk in front of Fenerbahce Ulker forward Nikola Kalinic (33) in the third quarter of an NBA basketball preseason ... more Image 3 of 4 San Antonio Spurs forward Kawhi Leonard, right, shoots over Sacramento Kings guard Rajon Rondo during the first quarter of an NBA preseason basketball game in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. San Antonio Spurs forward Kawhi Leonard, right, shoots over Sacramento Kings guard Rajon Rondo during the first quarter of an NBA preseason basketball game in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015. Photo: Rich Pedroncelli /Associated Press Image 4 of 4 Cleveland Cavaliers’ LeBron James plays against the Memphis Grizzlies during an NBA basketball game Monday, Oct. 12, 2015, in Columbus, Ohio. Cleveland Cavaliers’ LeBron James plays against the Memphis Grizzlies during an NBA basketball game Monday, Oct. 12, 2015, in Columbus, Ohio. Photo: Jay LaPrete /Associated Press Spurs Nation: Beat writers gaze into their crystal ball 1 / 4 Back to Gallery Express-News staff writers make their predictions for the 2015-16 NBA season:
BUCK HARVEY
Spurs 2015-16 record: 57-25 — There will be bumps. There will also be nights when LaMarcus Aldridge blends so well the Spurs look like the league’s best. And little of it will matter until April.
Atlantic Division winner: Toronto — Destined to be first in the division, destined to lose in the first round.
Central Division winner: Cleveland — David Blatt shows improvement after a season at the right hand of LeBron James .
Southeast Division winner: Atlanta — Assuming he left his sore calf behind in San Antonio, Tiago Splitter becomes a quiet, underappreciated factor in the East.
Pacific Division winner: Golden State — If Steve Kerr remains the only one in the franchise who suffers an injury, the Warriors will be a top-two seed.
Southwest Division winner: Houston — While the Spurs will slowly reform the way they play, the Rockets will plug in Ty Lawson and go faster.
Northwest Division winner: Oklahoma City — Billy Donovan is blessed to begin his NBA coaching career with this roster. He’s also blessed to be in this division.
Eastern Conference champion: Cleveland — They don’t even have a clear-cut challenger within the conference.
Western Conference champion: Oklahoma City — Finally free of injury, the talent rises.
NBA champion: Oklahoma City — Kevin Durant gets a ring, as well as a reason to stay.
Rookie of year: Jahlil Okafor — Tanking nearly over, Sixers direct their offense to an NBA-ready rookie.
Defensive player of year: Anthony Davis — Voters will be reluctant to see the Pelicans star as the MVP, since standings are often tied to the award. So this will be his consolation prize.
MVP: LeBron James — Still the game’s best.
JEFF MCDONALD
Spurs 2015-16 record: 61-21 — Offseason additions of LaMarcus Aldridge and David West will help the Spurs better navigate the grind of the regular season and return them to the 60-win club.
Atlantic Division winner: Toronto — The Raptors remain the cream of a dreadful crop, but they’ll have to hold off a Boston team on the rise.
Central Division winner: Cleveland — The Cavs won 53 games in the first season of LeBron James’ homecoming. Take the over this year.
Southeast Division winner: Miami — With Chris Bosh healthy and the Heat (somewhat) reloaded, look for Miami to return to the playoffs.
Pacific Division winner: Golden State — With a target on their backs, the defending champs will have their work cut out to fend off the improved L.A. Clippers .
Southwest Division winner: Spurs — The Spurs gave away the division on the last day of the regular season last year, but cruise with room to spare in 2015-16.
Northwest Division winner: Oklahoma City — So long as Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook can stay healthy together, OKC has no strong challenger for the Northwest crown.
Eastern Conference champion: Cleveland — Does any team out East have what it takes to dethrone King James and the Cavs? We think not.
Western Conference champion: Spurs — It will be a bloodbath, but the Spurs have the talent plus experience to emerge from a mess of true contenders that includes Golden State, OKC and the L.A. Clippers.
NBA champion: Spurs — This time, perhaps, Tim Duncan will go out on top.
Rookie of year: De’Angelo Russell — Sweet-passing guard will get plenty of run, playing with the rebuilding Lakers.
Defensive player of year: Kawhi Leonard — The first wing player in 11 years to win the NBA’s top defensive award, the Spurs’ small forward will make it back-to-back.
MVP: Kevin Durant — KD comes back with a vengeance after last season’s lost year — just in time to hit the free-agent market.
TOM ORSBORN
Spurs 2015-16 record: 56-26 — It’s tempting to predict a 60-win season, but questions surround chemistry, Tony Parker and bench.
Atlantic Division winner: Toronto — An infusion of youth, including ex-Spur Cory Joseph, keeps them atop NBA’s weakest division.
Central Division winner: Cleveland — The mission is simple: secure home-court advantage in the Finals.
Southeast Division winner: Atlanta — They won’t win 60 again, but they should be good for the East’s 2 seed.
Pacific Division winner: Golden State — They’re the hunted now, but that shouldn’t stop them from another title chase.
Southwest Division winner: Spurs — Toughest team in toughest division.
Northwest Division winner: Oklahoma City — Kevin Durant returns to form for new coach Billy Donovan.
East champion: Cleveland — Aided by return of Kevin Love and Kyrie Irving, LeBron James gets another shot at third title.
West champion: Golden State — The Warriors have it all again — talent, depth, coaching.
NBA champion: Cleveland — In Finals rematch, Cavs gain revenge; James wins MVP.
Rookie of the year: Jahlil Okafor. In a conference thin on stellar big men, he will shine for the Sixers.
Defensive player of year: Kawhi Leonard — They’ll have to rename this award in his honor by the time he’s done.
MVP: Anthony Davis — Already a two-time All-Star at 22, he’ll flourish in Alvin Gentry ’s up-tempo scheme.
MIKE MONROE
Spurs 2015-16 record: 57-25: It will take time for a revamped roster to develop championship synergy; 60-win season is unrealistic.
Atlantic Division winner: Toronto —Their core is intact and they added role players who are solid defenders and glue guys.
Southeast Division winner: Miami —They’ve had a full year to get over LeBron’s defection; Hassan Whiteside is All-Star waiting to happen.
Central Division winner: Cleveland — Opening without Irving will be tough but Mo Williams will hold the fort for team with NBA’s best player.
Southwest Division winner: Houston — Ty Lawson just what they needed to take the next step.
Northwest Division winner: Oklahoma City: A new coach. A healthy superstar. And a giant chip on collective shoulder.
Pacific Division winner: Golden State —Defending title incredibly difficult but young, talented core is intact.
Eastern Conference champion: Cleveland — LeBron James will get his seventh trip to The NBA Finals because he is that good and his team deeper.
Western Conference champion: Golden State — The scary thing about the defending champs is fact they are so young.
NBA champion: Golden State —What will a fifth loss in a seventh NBA Finals do to LeBron’s legacy?
Rookie of the Year: Kristaps Porzingis
Defensive Player of the Year: Kawhi Leonard
MVP: LeBron James
JABARI YOUNG
Spurs 2015-16 record: 60-22. Health will play a major role with the Spurs. Anything major may cut this prediction down to about 50-55 wins, but with all that offensive power, this team should have no problem getting 60 victories or more.
Atlantic Division winner: Toronto — Kyle Lowry dedicated his offseason to getting fit and looks great early on. Add DeMarre Carroll to the mix - that defense should be solid.
Central Division winner: Cleveland —The Bulls will be lurking, with the Bucks sneaking up, too, but last I checked LeBron James is still playing.
Southeast Division winner: Washington —Carroll’s loss will hurt Atlanta. Meanwhile, John Wall is healthy, Bradley Beal still has a lot to prove, the Wizards are legit.
Northwest Division winner: Oklahoma City — Short and sweet: Kevin Durant is back, Russell Westbrook’s play is on another planet. Enough said.
Pacific Division winner: Los Angeles Clippers — Some still believe the Warriors were lucky to win the championship last season. I’m one of those people. The Clippers are deeper and more prepared to take back the division.
Southwest Division winner: Houston —This is a dangerous team that shouldn’t be taken lightly. James Harden is a bad man, Dwight Howard seems healthy, and Ty Lawson’s addition will help.
Eastern Conference champion: Cleveland — Again, James is still playing, Kevin Love is back, and if Kyrie Irving stays healthy throughout the playoffs, the Cavs have more than enough to repeat as conference champions.
Western Conference champion: Spurs/Thunder —The rules say pick one, but I can’t. It will comes down these two teams (health permitting). Spurs are more experienced, but OKC has always given them problems. Should be a great Western Conf. Finals.
NBA champion: Cavaliers will get there, and if the Spurs are the opponent, Cleveland will once again suffer disappointment. If it’s the Thunder, LeBron will finally bring one home.
Rookie of the Year: Jahlil Okafor
Defensive Player of the Year: Draymond Green
MVP: Anthony Davis
sports@express-news.net
